5. Smoldering myeloma. For the one third who meet criteria for high risk smoldering myeloma, recommend therapy with  Len or Len/Dex for 2 years or clinical trial. #ASH22 https://t.co/XUKxCngyT6

4. Second on higher  relapse. Try one of the first relapse regimens that the patient is not refractory to. #ASH22 

Triple refractory: Either alkylator or BCMA targeted therapy. 

BCMA refractory options also listed below. https://t.co/3dfjHxAQha
3. First relapse. The approach depends on refractoriness to Len and CD38moAB. For CD38 Moab either Daratumumab or Isatuximab are OK. Depends on cost and availability. #ASH22 https://t.co/Nw0afMaOxF

2. Newly Diagnosed myeloma transplant eligible. #ASH22

Early transplant preferred. But for selected standard risk patients depending on preference, delayed is also OK. Maintenance varies by risk stratification. https://t.co/pfV83LhB5R

Updated Myeloma Treatment Algorithms presented at @IMFmyeloma @CCO_Education symposium  today at #ASH22

-Relapse from CR or MRD- ?

RT @OncLive: Rajkumar Previews CAR-T Updates, Elranatamab Findings in Multiple Myeloma Ahead of ASH 2022 @VincentRK @MayoCancerCare @ASH_he…

My thoughts on SMM were shaped and influenced years ago through conversations with Drs. Kyle, San Miguel, Merlini, Landgren, Mateos, Lonial, Kumar, Durie, Paiva, Dimopoulos, and many others. 

So glad to see continued progress.

I must say many leaders in the field share the same vision and commitment with regards to SMM. And are doing a range of studies and trials in this regard, especially @IreneGhobrial and @DrOlaLandgren 

The full spectrum of studies is what it will take to solve this puzzle.
@barttels2 @DeVitaDoctor Agree.  And same for me.  Amazing book. Strongly recommend to all oncologists.

Finally @MunshiNc is on Twitter! Follow him if interested in hematology or myeloma. #ASH22 

Dr. Nikhil Munshi is the President of the International Myeloma Society, and the Kraft Family Chair @DanaFarber @harvardmed

We have the same vision and goal. For me it was inspired by @DeVitaDoctor and how he approached cure in Hodgkin lymphoma: Cure means fixed duration therapy, stop treatment, the disease never ever comes back in a reasonable proportion of patients.  

That’s what we are going for.
RT @chadinabhan: I love the fact that this is a fixed duration study and explores MRD. I believe curing a disease requires eradication at t…

@chadinabhan @ASH_hematology Yes. Cure means fixed duration therapy, stop treatment, the disease never ever comes back in a reasonable proportion of patients.  

That’s what we are going for.

This is a multi decade vision. I’m glad the trials were started and we already have years of follow up. 

Congrats to @mvmateos and @myelomaMD for overcoming numerous obstacles to get us to this point.

There will be successor trials similar to CESAR and ASCENT. If and when the results look very promising the next step would be to compare the winning regimen from one of the Cure trials to whatever is standard of care at the time in a randomized trial.

It will be a decade or two to determine whether we are successful. The natural history of high risk SMM with observation or mild therapy is known. The goal with the Cure trials is to see if there is a plateau in disease free survival that’s enduring & far beyond what’s expected.

These trials are part of a planned series of trials investigating whether the incurability of myeloma is related to the fact that we have traditionally started effective therapy only after the disease has spread and mutated to the point where it is no longer curable.

data.text:
I like this #ASH22 abstract examining fixed duration of cevostamab in relapsed myeloma. 

Bispecifics will be extraordinarily expensive and carry significant infection risk with prolonged use. We need to study fixed duration treatment. @LesokhinMD et al. https://t.co/R93xAhzkjo
@PedalheadPHX @ASH_hematology @jmikhaelmd I have no idea whether I did or not. I’ll just pick it up there. No stickers for me.

Once I make an assessment that someone is sealioning, I will permanently mute and not respond. 

I have not blocked anyone so far on Twitter. But I do mute rudeness and nonsense liberally.

@wangyub As always use judgment. If you have 40% bone marrow PCs and the only MDE is 2 focal lesions on MRI, that’s likely MM and you wouldn’t need to biopsy or wait. If you have only 12% PCs the you may want to biopsy or wait and repeat imaging. Also depends on FLC level and ratio.

@wangyub The criteria are very specific on how to use the MRI. If that’s the only MDE you need bone marrow with >=10% clonal plasma cells and 2 or more definite focal lesions on MRI at least 5mm in size. If in doubt wait 3-6 months and repeat. Diffuse abnormalities or signal is not MDE.
RT @AkivaDiamond: Great thread on the 2014 IMWG criteria. Several points in this brief thread are often misunderstood. I want to highlight…

@MichaelJSlade @CyclingDoctor @LabFehniger @DiPersioLab @AaronGoodman33 @ManniMD1 @DavidSteensma @bdermanmd @VPrasadMDMPH @myelomaMD @Geoff_Uy If you are not focused on a disease it’s still good to decide whether your focus is on clinical abstracts or lab and then do the same exercise of picking about 25 ones you really are interested in. 

Attend a couple oral sessions a day and walk by the posters and meet colleagues.

@MichaelJSlade @CyclingDoctor @LabFehniger @DiPersioLab @AaronGoodman33 @ManniMD1 @DavidSteensma @bdermanmd @VPrasadMDMPH @myelomaMD @Geoff_Uy I usually apply the oral session filter and the field I’m interested in (myeloma) and quickly scan through the abstracts, printing ones I feel are important for me. The exercise then of picking my top 5 each year ensures I read the ones I print (about ~25) closely.
@szusmani Absolutely. Thanks Saad.
RT @szusmani: This thread 👇🏽 #ASH22, a testament to the collaborative nature of the #mmsm community.

Im not an insulin user. But as physician advocate for lower insulin prices, I think this will be a life saver. #MedTwitter #Insulin4all @DavidP4AD 

Thanks @costplusdrugs https://t.co/GzfDFiSrZR

For those interested the paper which was previously the most cited paper ever in myeloma was the 1975 Durie Salmon staging system with 3940 citations.  

(Citations as captured in Google Scholar)

12/ This is all thanks & credit to IMWG & coauthors. Jesus San Miguel, Giampaolo Merlini, Ken Anderson, Bob Kyle. Many are on Twitter: @thanosdimop @mvmateos @myelomaMD @BrianDurieMD @SagarLonialMD @szusmani @ADispenzieri @sykristinsson @DrOlaLandgren @mbeksac56 @BrunoPaiva_UNAV https://t.co/dmqkEouveg

11/ There’s a lot more in this paper. The authors worked on many drafts to ensure we got it right and had consensus. 

I have never worked on a paper where every single sentence has so much importance and meaning as in this paper.
10/ CRAB features do not need to be symptomatic.

9/ Infections, suppression of uninvolved immunoglobulins are not considered myeloma defining events. Too non specific. Patients must meet one of the 7 myeloma defining events defined in the criteria to be considered as having myeloma.
8/ Presence of clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow biopsy is not needed for diagnosis of myeloma. Presence of a biopsy proven plasmacytoma with another myeloma defining event is sufficient.

7/ Presence of serum or urine M protein is not necessary for myeloma diagnosis. Non secretory myeloma is myeloma and treated as such. It’s not a separate disease. It’s more of a description, and it’s understood that monitoring will be different in such patients.

6/ Only light chain cast nephropathy qualifies as a myeloma defining renal event. All other renal lesions attributable to monoclonal protein are considered unique disorders and do not automatically mean malignancy or meet the criteria for myeloma diagnosis.

5/ Clarification and recommendations for   advanced imaging (CT, PET-CT ) to detect lytic bone lesions. 

To distinguish MM from SMM, MRI imaging may be needed.
4/ MGUS was formally classified into 3 types with specific diagnostic criteria outlined for each. #ASH22 #MedTwitter https://t.co/f7Cjf06vM3
3/ We simultaneously updated the diagnostic criteria for related plasma cell disorders including MGUS, SMM, and solitary plasmacytoma. https://t.co/D9l07jzAP6

2/ The paradigm shifting  change was including 3 biomarkers that were associated with 80% or greater probability of progression within 2 years as myeloma defining events on top of CRAB. 

>100 myeloma experts gave input for the paper. #ASH22 #MedTwitter https://t.co/ZoIwF4QgOZ

urls.title: International Myeloma Working Group updated criteria for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma
urls.description: This International Myeloma Working Group consensus updates the disease definition of multiple myeloma to include validated biomarkers in addition to existing requirements of attributable CRAB features (hypercalcaemia, renal failure, anaemia, and bone lesions). These changes are based on the identification of biomarkers associated with near inevitable development of CRAB features in patients who would otherwise be regarded as having smouldering multiple myeloma. A delay in application of the label of multiple myeloma and postponement of therapy could be detrimental to these patients.

Patients have already paid their premiums. They have deductibles and copays. They need assurance that when they need healthcare they will get the best care they need and what the physician they trust recommends.

urls.title: Smoldering multiple myeloma current treatment algorithms
urls.description: Blood Cancer Journal - Smoldering multiple myeloma current treatment algorithms

data.text:
@DrTJM_MD We enroll patients on trials as the default. Rd vs DRd is the current phase III. 

Off study, practice varies. Most of us who have studied SMM in detail recommend treating newly diagnosed HR SMM with Len or Len/dex for 2 years as outlined in this paper. https://t.co/iJ4X6XOI2g

@DrTJM_MD We could recommend triplet for HR SMM now. But we lack of RCT data that it’s better than Len or Rd. Why we do the RCTs 

Secondly, you and I can give VRd or DRd to well insured US patients now. Most others in the world we won’t be able to help absent RCTs and regulatory approval.

urls.title: Global Partners May End Broad Covid Vaccination Effort in Developing Countries
urls.description: The board of Gavi, the international vaccine agency, meets Wednesday to debate shutting down the program, known as Covax, amid swiftly waning demand for the shots.

tweets.text:
The global vax campaign is far more unequal today than it was earlier in the pandemic. 

Booster momentum is close to 0 in developing countries. 

Amidst all this, Covax may be shut down. 

Is it the right time?

I must say many leaders in the field share the same vision and commitment with regards to SMM. And are doing a range of studies and trials in this regard, especially @IreneGhobrial and @DrOlaLandgren 

The full spectrum of studies is what it will take to solve this puzzle.

We have the same vision and goal. For me it was inspired by @DeVitaDoctor and how he approached cure in Hodgkin lymphoma: Cure means fixed duration therapy, stop treatment, the disease never ever comes back in a reasonable proportion of patients.  

That’s what we are going for.
@VincentRK @DeVitaDoctor I believe I’ve mentioned that The Death of Cancer is my favorite book on the subject. Definitely also the most fearless and most fun.

This is a multi decade vision. I’m glad the trials were started and we already have years of follow up. 

Congrats to @mvmateos and @myelomaMD for overcoming numerous obstacles to get us to this point.

I love the fact that this is a fixed duration study and explores MRD. I believe curing a disease requires eradication at the molecular level. Trials will determine that. #ASH22 @ASH_hematology https://t.co/b6P5onvY5g

There will be successor trials similar to CESAR and ASCENT. If and when the results look very promising the next step would be to compare the winning regimen from one of the Cure trials to whatever is standard of care at the time in a randomized trial.

It will be a decade or two to determine whether we are successful. The natural history of high risk SMM with observation or mild therapy is known. The goal with the Cure trials is to see if there is a plateau in disease free survival that’s enduring & far beyond what’s expected.

These trials are part of a planned series of trials investigating whether the incurability of myeloma is related to the fact that we have traditionally started effective therapy only after the disease has spread and mutated to the point where it is no longer curable.

urls.title: Paper: Curative Strategy (GEM-CESAR) for High-Risk Smoldering Myeloma (SMM): Post-Hoc Analysis of Sustained Undetectable Measurable Residual Disease (MRD)
urls.description: Program: Oral and Poster Abstracts Type: Oral Session: 731. tweets.text:
Updated results from the 1st Cure trial, GEM-CESAR led by @mvmateos is also being presented at #ASH22

https://t.co/RAdqP5Dfl0

Here are my Top 5 #ASH22 @ASH_hematology myeloma abstracts. #ASH22VR  
Links to the full abstract. As in the past, I left out studies where similar results were already presented or published before. Top 5 based on new data, clinical impact & methodology

Thread with countdown👇
Great thread to revisit and understand the The IMWG updated diagnostic criteria for myeloma & related disorders by @VincentRK https://t.co/oBEMJJJedH
Second year in a row I didn’t get my @ASH_hematology meeting badge in the mail. Would not compete with @jmikhaelmd on stickers but getting ripped off again

@wangyub The criteria are very specific on how to use the MRI. If that’s the only MDE you need bone marrow with >=10% clonal plasma cells and 2 or more definite focal lesions on MRI at least 5mm in size. If in doubt wait 3-6 months and repeat. Diffuse abnormalities or signal is not MDE.
@VincentRK Is MRI producing more false positive bone lesions? We get consult about abnormal MRI bone marrow signals quite often and rarely showed any positive findings on biopsy.
Great thread on the 2014 IMWG criteria. Several points in this brief thread are often misunderstood. I want to highlight two tweets, but the entire thread is gold. https://t.co/q1x3bbqou2

@MichaelJSlade @CyclingDoctor @LabFehniger @DiPersioLab @AaronGoodman33 @ManniMD1 @DavidSteensma @bdermanmd @VPrasadMDMPH @myelomaMD @Geoff_Uy I usually apply the oral session filter and the field I’m interested in (myeloma) and quickly scan through the abstracts, printing ones I feel are important for me. The exercise then of picking my top 5 each year ensures I read the ones I print (about ~25) closely.

As a trainee who’s overwhelmed by the volume of abstracts for #ASH2022, any advice on filtering/reviewing/scheduling from the senior folks?

@CyclingDoctor @LabFehniger @DiPersioLab @AaronGoodman33 @ManniMD1 @DavidSteensma @bdermanmd @VPrasadMDMPH @VincentRK @myelomaMD @Geoff_Uy
This thread 👇🏽 #ASH22, a testament to the collaborative nature of the #mmsm community. https://t.co/FZK1jDmJvj

Insulin users: we are evaluating a future insulin test program and would like your feedback.

If we offered a 90-day supply of a fast-acting insulin (up to 12 vials/8 packs of pens) for $170 incl. shipping, what would you think?

Share you feedback here: https://t.co/F2BNPLOOtn https://t.co/O5JPTMsE45

urls.title: Fill | Insulin Test Feedback
urls.description: This form is intended for insulin users only.  We are evaluating a test program for insulin and would like feedback from insulin users. For this test, we would make a 90-day supply of a fast-acting insulin available for $170.00, up to 12 vials or 8 packs of pens. The insulin would be shipped directly to your home.

tweets.text: 12/ This is all thanks & credit to IMWG & coauthors. Jesus San Miguel, Giampaolo Merlini, Ken Anderson, Bob Kyle. Many are on Twitter: @thanosdimop @mvmateos @myelomaMD @BrianDurieMD @SagarLonialMD @szusmani @ADispenzieri @sykristinsson @DrOlaLandgren @mbeksac56 @BrunoPaiva_UNAV https://t.co/dmqkEouveg

11/ There’s a lot more in this paper. The authors worked on many drafts to ensure we got it right and had consensus. 

I have never worked on a paper where every single sentence has so much importance and meaning as in this paper.
10/ CRAB features do not need to be symptomatic.

9/ Infections, suppression of uninvolved immunoglobulins are not considered myeloma defining events. Too non specific. Patients must meet one of the 7 myeloma defining events defined in the criteria to be considered as having myeloma.
8/ Presence of clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow biopsy is not needed for diagnosis of myeloma. Presence of a biopsy proven plasmacytoma with another myeloma defining event is sufficient.

7/ Presence of serum or urine M protein is not necessary for myeloma diagnosis. Non secretory myeloma is myeloma and treated as such. It’s not a separate disease. It’s more of a description, and it’s understood that monitoring will be different in such patients.

6/ Only light chain cast nephropathy qualifies as a myeloma defining renal event. All other renal lesions attributable to monoclonal protein are considered unique disorders and do not automatically mean malignancy or meet the criteria for myeloma diagnosis.

5/ Clarification and recommendations for   advanced imaging (CT, PET-CT ) to detect lytic bone lesions. 

To distinguish MM from SMM, MRI imaging may be needed.
4/ MGUS was formally classified into 3 types with specific diagnostic criteria outlined for each. #ASH22 #MedTwitter https://t.co/f7Cjf06vM3
3/ We simultaneously updated the diagnostic criteria for related plasma cell disorders including MGUS, SMM, and solitary plasmacytoma. https://t.co/D9l07jzAP6

2/ The paradigm shifting  change was including 3 biomarkers that were associated with 80% or greater probability of progression within 2 years as myeloma defining events on top of CRAB. 

>100 myeloma experts gave input for the paper. #ASH22 #MedTwitter https://t.co/ZoIwF4QgOZ

urls.title: International Myeloma Working Group updated criteria for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma
urls.description: This International Myeloma Working Group consensus updates the disease definition of multiple myeloma to include validated biomarkers in addition to existing requirements of attributable CRAB features (hypercalcaemia, renal failure, anaemia, and bone lesions). These changes are based on the identification of biomarkers associated with near inevitable development of CRAB features in patients who would otherwise be regarded as having smouldering multiple myeloma. A delay in application of the label of multiple myeloma and postponement of therapy could be detrimental to these patients.

tweets.text:
Just in time for #ASH22

The IMWG updated diagnostic criteria for myeloma & related disorders has just become the most cited myeloma paper ever. @TheLancetOncol #MedTwitter https://t.co/61ohPFLtGi

I was honored to lead this effort for the IMWG. A thread on the main changes. 
1/

It’s a complicated landscape and I have tried to make it simple for practicing clinicians. 

There are changes compared to prior years. @mtmdphd @Mohty_EBMT #MedTwitter https://t.co/ViJGEFUBTH

Very grateful to have received my flu shot in mid-October.

Make sure to get yours! https://t.co/zGnVfgzN0e
Vulnerable patients who are already suffering from their illness should not have the added problem of fighting with insurance companies for coverage. Reform is needed.
@VincentRK Our Doctors should not have to fight with them either.

@VincentRK Sounds good! Thanks for explaining this! So my assumption is that at Mayo clinic, it is standard practice to treat HR - SMM with either Len or Len dex. Observation is rarely an option in your practice (if at all offered). Is that correct?

@VincentRK If we want to treat HR - SMM, why not treat with RVD? I'd think since one will be on treatment until death (most of them), I would rather want pts maximum time off any treatment as long as possible, especially if asymptomatic. Don't you think there should be a obs arm as well?

Seeing media coverage about measles and polio outbreaks which is just sad given it’s preventable…

But nothing yet about the disastrous ID fellowship match. 

We are definitely not ready for pandemics of future. 

We not even ready for infectious diseases of the past right now!
